10.1016/j.mcat.2024.114618 The Author(s) Scheme 1 Asymmetric alkylation of amino acid enolates according to the literature [28–31] and the current work. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 Schematic structure of the complexes explored in this work. Fig 1 Scheme 2 Schematic representation of the route to the Cα-alkylation of the amino acid derivatives described in this work. Scheme 2 Fig. 2 Proposed structure of the intermediate binuclear complex catalyst in the transition state of the alkylation: (a) complex 4; (b) complex 6. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Calculated structures of binuclear Cu(II) complexes (6) in a conformation (a) with coordination of the allyl fragment with a complexing metal, (b) without coordination of the allyl fragment. ΔG = −10.29 kJ/mol. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Proposed structure of the transition state of the binuclear Zn(II) ion of the 2 complex. Fig 4 Fig. 5 DFT optimized structures of complexes: a. propeller-like structure of unsubstituted binuclear Zn(II) ion complex (1); b. cross-like structure of unsubstituted binuclear Cu(II) ion complex (4); c. 3‑methoxy substituted binuclear Zn(II) ion complex (2) with restored cross-like structure. In this study, we present a series of Zn(II) mono- and Cu(II) binuclear salen complexes synthesized and assessed for their effectiveness in the Cα-alkylation reaction. Through systematic experimentation, it was observed that the introduction of a methoxy group at position 3 of the phenyl group in the salicylidene ligand led to a notable enhancement in asymmetric yield, while an allyl group reduced yield. Computational DFT calculations supported the involvement of the binuclear complex in the transition state of the reaction, elucidating the underlying mechanisms governing the observed catalytic behavior. A newly synthesized binuclear complex exhibited significantly higher catalytic activity compared to its mononuclear counterpart which could potentially be explained by increased intramolecular rigidity. This comprehensive investigation not only advances our understanding of structure-activity relationships in chiral salen complexes but also provides valuable insights for the rational design and optimization of catalysts for the asymmetric Cα-alkylation reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mono- Binuclear salen complex DFT, Cα-alkylation reaction Asymmetric catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Exploring the synthesis of non-protein α-amino acids stands as a critical pursuit, given their widespread utility in crucial domains like biomedicine and materials chemistry [1–7]. The development of efficient and simple methods for the synthesis of enantioenriched non-protein α-amino acids is an extremely important task, since they, as irreversible enzyme inhibitors, are widely used in numerous biomedical applications [8–10]. Among the various non-proteinogenic amino acids, various α,α-disubstituted amino acids, whether in isolation or as components of peptides, exhibit potential pharmacological activity [11–15]. One of the potentially straightforward method for synthesizing unnatural α-amino acids is α-C(sp3)−H alkylation of α-amino acids or their derivatives. However, only a few examples have been reported, including those by Zhaon [16], Yamamoto [17], Yazaki and Ohshima [18,19] et al., all of which require catalysts and additives. On the other hand, numerous methods have been described for the catalytic asymmetric synthesis of unnatural amino acids by hydrogenation of olefins and imines [20,21] electrophilic amination of enolates [22,23], electrophilic alkylation of glycine derivatives [24] and nucleophilic addition to α-imino esters [25], among others. Chiral transition metal complexes, particularly those studied by North and Belokon, are effective catalysts for the asymmetric alkylation of amino acid enolates via phase transfer catalysis [26]. Salen complexes are coordination compounds derived from the condensation of a salicylaldehyde (sal) with an diamine (en), with the resulting ligand being a bis(salicylidene)ethylenediamine, hence the name „salen“. These complexes typically feature a metal ion coordinated to the nitrogen atoms of the ethylenediamine backbone and the deprotonated oxygen atoms of the salicylaldehyde moieties. Salen complexes are widely studied for their diverse applications, including catalysis, coordination chemistry, and materials science and are known for their versatile coordination environments and tunable properties, making them valuable in various chemical and biological contexts [27]. Different chiral metal salen complexes have been tested as catalysts for the asymmetric alkylation of amino acid enolates via phase transfer catalysis [28–30] (Scheme 1 a). In a previous study, we examined the performance of Cu(II) and Ni(II) salen complexes, derived from the Schiff base of cyclohexyldiamine and various substituted salicylaldehydes, as phase transfer catalysts. These catalysts were evaluated in the context of Cα-alkylation reactions involving benzylideneimine substrates, specifically Schiff bases derived from the isopropyl ester of D,L-alanine and substituted benzaldehydes reacting with benzyl bromide [31] (Scheme 1b). The present work reports the synthesis of mono-salen complexes of the Zn(II) ion and compares their catalytic activity with that of similarly designed Cu(II) and Ni(II) ion complexes in the Cα-alkylation reactions of the amino acid moiety of benzylideneimine substrates (Scheme 1c). It is noteworthy that although mono-salen complexes of the Zn(II) ion have been previously synthesized, their catalytic properties have not yet been investigated [32,33]. Additionally, for the first time, binuclear salen complexes of the Cu(II) ion have been synthesized. Overall, this study represents a multidisciplinary effort encompassing synthetic chemistry, experimental catalysis, and computational modelling, aimed at advancing our fundamental understanding of chiral salen complexes as catalysts for asymmetric synthesis of molecules of interest in different fields like materials science and biomedicine. The insights gained from this research have the potential to inform the rational design and optimization of future catalysts, contributing to the broader field of asymmetric synthesis and catalysis. 2 Results and discussion Aiming at evaluating the catalytic activity of the synthesized complexes, we conducted asymmetric Cα-alkylation reactions of the amino acid moiety of different substrates with benzyl bromide, allyl bromide, and propargyl bromide as model reactions. In more detail, we present the salen complexes involving Zn(II) ions and compare their catalytic efficacy with that of similarly designed Cu(II) and Ni(II) complexes in the Cα-alkylation reactions of the amino acid moiety within benzylideneimine substrates (Fig. 1 ). Notably, in this study, the salen complexes containing Zn(II) (1–3) are tested as catalysts for the first time. To test the catalytic activity of the synthesized complexes, the asymmetric Cα-alkylation of the amino acid moiety of substrates 10–12 with benzyl bromide, allyl bromide and propargyl bromide was chosen as a model reaction (Scheme 2 ). In the case of the Cα-alkylation of the amino acid moiety of substrates 10–12 with allyl bromide during catalysis by complexes of Cu(II) and Zn(II) ions, an increase in the asymmetric yield of the alkylation product was observed in a number of substrates of isopropyl esters of N-4-chlorobenzylidenealanine (10), N-4-fluorobenzylidenealanine (11), and 2‑chloro-N-benzylidenealanine (12) (Table 1 ). In the case of using unsubstituted salen metal complexes, an increase in the asymmetric induction is observed in the series of transition metal complexes Zn(II), Ni(II), Cu(II). A notable pattern emerges in the asymmetric induction of the Cα-alkylation reaction based on the substituent in the salicylidene fragment of the catalyst. Specifically, complexes featuring a 3‑methoxy-substituted salicylidene fragment, such as the 3‑methoxy-substituted salen complexes of Zn(II) and Cu(II) ions, demonstrate the highest catalytic activity (Table 1, exp. 2 and 5). However, the introduction of the allyl group into position 3 of the salicylidene fragment of complexes (3,6,9) sharply reduces the asymmetric yield (trends to zero). An explanation for this phenomenon can be found based on the hypothetical model of the mechanism of the alkylation reaction proposed by Yu.N. Belokon and M. North [30,34]. According to this mechanism, both transition and alkali (Na+) metal ions are involved in the alkylation transition state. A bimetallic derivative is formed, in which the sodium ion is coordinated with the oxygen atoms of the salen part of the complexes, while the ionized substrate and the alkylating agent are coordinated with the transition metal ions (Fig. 2 a). We assume that in the case of complexes 3, 6 and 9, the allyl group at position 3 of the salicylidene fragment is additionally coordinated with the transition metal ion, thus blocking coordination of the ionized substrate and the alkylating agent on the coordination sphere of the binuclear complex (Fig. 2b). This leads to a decrease in both the chemical yield and the asymmetric induction. The limited solubility of Zn and Ni Salen complexes posed a significant challenge, effectively hindering the ability to conduct meaningful kinetic studies with these systems. This solubility issue restricts the generation of reliable kinetic data, thereby limiting the scope of comparative analysis. Additionally, the paramagnetic nature of Cu Salen complexes introduces further complexities, particularly in the context of NMR spectroscopy. The paramagnetism of Cu severely compromises the resolution and interpretability of NMR spectra, rendering kinetic experiments involving these complexes impractical. These combined factors constrain our ability to acquire the necessary kinetic data for a comprehensive comparison between the monometallic and dimeric complexes. In light of these limitations, Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations emerge as the most viable and productive approach for elucidating the underlying catalytic mechanisms. To assess the contribution of possible coordination of the allyl fragment with the transition metal ion, conformational analysis of the formed binuclear complex was performed using Density Functional Theory (DFT) [35]. In fact, DFT calculations provide valuable insights into the electronic structure, energetics, and reaction mechanisms of chemical systems. In the DFT study, only two dynamically stable conformers were found, one of which has 3 of 4 allyl fragments coordinated with the transition metal ion, and the other with only one of the four possible (Fig. 3 a). This analysis was performed for both Cu(II) and Zn(II) complexes. The standard Gibbs free energy change in this coordination was −10.73 kJ/mol and −10.29 kJ/mol for Zn(II) and Cu(II) complexes, respectively. This means that binuclear complex conformations with additionally coordinated allyl fragments, with blocked catalytic site of the complex, significantly predominate in the solution, hence leading to a decrease in catalytic activity. The stereoselective alkylation reaction course gets hindered, which leads to poor enantioselectivity of the reaction observed in the experimental data. The chemical characteristic of allyl coordination is also confirmed by Hirschfeld charge calculations [36] concentrated on the transition metal ions. Upon detachment of the allyl fragment, the charge on the metal ion shifts from +0.4 to +0.48 for Zn(II) complexes and from +0.2 to +0.24 for Cu(II) complexes. The salen complex catalyzes the asymmetric alkylation of enolates through an SN2 mechanism, enhancing enolate nucleophilicity [37]. Transitioning from Cu(II) to Ni(II) complexes reduces the metal ion's total charge, leading to decreased enantiomeric yield [31]. However, within the series of Zn(II) salicylidene complexes, the following phenomenon is observed: in the case of complexes 1 and 3, this hypothesis coincides, since the asymmetric yield is much less than in the case of complexes 4, 6, 7 and 9 (Table 1). And in the case of complex 2, the value of the asymmetric yield is high and does not yield to those of complexes 5 and 8. Based on certain observations in Kostakis's work [38], we assume that upon introduction of a methoxy group into position 3 of the salicylidene fragment of the metal complex, due to its additional coordination with the sodium ion, the rigidity of the intramolecular structure of the bimetallic derivative increases, which contributes to the asymmetric induction (Fig. 4 ). To determine the effect of the transition metal and of the substituents on the stability of the proposed catalyst, the formation energies of such binuclear complexes from two mononuclear ones were calculated. DFT calculations showed that the association of 3OCH3–-substituted complexes 2, 5 and 3-allyl-substituted complexes 3, 6 through sodium ion is stronger than in the case of unsubstituted complexes 1, 4 (Table 2 ). These results are in agreement with the empirical conclusion, that the 3OCH3– -substituted complexes perform best as a catalyst. Higher number of methoxy groups interacting with bridging Na+ contribute to higher stability and rigidity of the dimer complex, also leaving the active site of the catalyst available for further reaction development. Zn(II) and Cu(II) complexes with same substituents have close enantioselective activity (Table 1). This rule is not conserved only for the unsubstituted Zn(II) complexes: Zn(II) catalyst (1) is inactive compared to analogous Cu(II) catalyst (4). This is explained by the structural twist in the Zn(II) complex. In DFT geometry optimization step in contrast to the Cu(II) complex, it was not possible to find a dimer in the case of an unsubstituted Zn(II) complex with the characteristic cross-like arrangement. Instead, the dimer of complex 1 was shown to have a dynamically stable propeller-like structure (Fig. 4a, 4b). The twist can be provoked by the positive charge accumulated on Zn(II) ion (+0.4 as compared to +0.2 on Cu(II)) pulling the aromatic rings. This arrangement does not allow reactant coordination on the binuclear complex in close proximity to each other, as described in proposed mechanism of the process (Fig. 4), but allows the coordination only on the opposite sides of the metal complex plane, hence abrupting the enantioselective catalysis. However, when 3‑methoxy substitution is introduced, the binuclear complex of Zn(II) recovers characteristic cross-like structure of the complex conditioned by methoxy(O)-Na+ interactions (Fig. 5 c). Then, to compare the stereodifferentiating ability of metal complexes, new modified zinc complexes were tested in the reactions of Cα-alkylation of the amino acid moiety of the substrates with benzyl bromide. The results are shown in Table 3 and Table 4 . As in the case of condensation with allyl bromide, the same pattern is also observed here: when using a substrate containing chlorine in the benzylidene fragment (10 and 12), the asymmetric yield is higher than in the case of F-containing substrate (11). Comparing the results on the alkylation of the amino acid moiety of substrates during catalysis by complexes containing the allyl group at position 3 of the salicylidene fragment (3,6,9) we observe that in the case of benzyl bromide as an alkylating agent, the induction of the reaction is approximately 2.5 times greater than in the case of allyl bromide. In our opinion, this is explained by the relatively higher ability of benzyl bromide, under the conditions of base catalysis, to coordinate with a transition metal ion compared to allyl bromide. We assume that partially ionized benzyl bromide displaces the allyl substituent of the salicylidene fragment of the complex from the coordination sphere of the metal, thereby promoting the coordination of the alkylating agent on the coordination sphere of the dimeric complex catalyst, which is the main factor in the manifestation of the stereodifferentiating aproperty of the catalyst. To obtain a complete picture of the stereodifferentiating ability of salen metal complexes, those with similar ligands (4–9) were also tested in the Cα-alkylation reactions of the amino acid moiety of new substrate 11 with propargyl bromide. Cα-alkylation of the amino acid of substrates with propargyl bromide under phase transfer catalysis using synthesized salen complexes proceeds in high chemical yields (conversion degree is in the order of 60–80 %). The results are shown in Table 5 . As evident from the data on the catalytic activity of complex catalysts, the pattern observed earlier is also repeated in the case of the Cα-alkylation reaction with propargyl bromide. It is important to note that the synthesis of the ligand utilized S,S-cyclohexanediamine, resulting in complexes with an S,S configuration. Additionally, the majority of the absolute configurations of the obtained amino acids are S. This study explores the feasibility of synthesizing and evaluating a binuclear dimer complex, building upon the proposed mechanism by Yu.N. Belokon and M. North regarding the participation of a salen complex catalyst in the transition state of alkylation as an ionically bound dimeric binuclear complex (Fig. 6 ) [30]. The catalytic efficiency of binuclear salen complex 16 with one molecule of Cu(OAc)2 (Fig. 6) was tested in the asymmetric Cα-alkylation reaction of 10 with allyl bromide (Scheme 2). The reaction displayed an induction of 88 %, significantly higher than that of corresponding mononuclear complexes 1 and 3 (Table 1). This increase in catalytic efficacy might be attributed to enhanced intramolecular rigidity upon transitioning from an ionically bound system to a covalently bound one. Overall, the study focuses on synthesizing and evaluating mono- and binuclear salen complexes for their catalytic activity in Cα-alkylation reactions of amino acids. It found that adding a methoxy group at position 3 of the phenyl group in the salicylidene ligand improved asymmetric yield, while an allyl group reduced it. DFT computational analyses explained these results, revealing the structure-activity relationships. Additionally, binuclear salen complexes showed much higher catalytic activity than mononuclear ones, suggesting promising directions for future catalyst design and optimization. 3 Conclusions In this study, we synthesized and characterized chiral Zn(II) mono- and Cu(II) binuclear salen complexes, alongside Ni(II) and Cu(II) chiral salen complexes, evaluated in Cα-alkylation reactions. Our results unveiled varying asymmetric yields contingent on the alkylating agent and substituent in the salicylidene fragment. Notably, complexes featuring a 3‑methoxy group at position 3 of the phenyl group exhibited heightened induction in Cα-alkylation reactions with allyl bromide. Computational analyses using DFT suggested that this effect may stem from enhanced stability of the binuclear complex during the transition state. Intriguingly, a binuclear salen complex demonstrated significantly elevated catalytic activity, potentially attributed to increased intramolecular rigidity. In future perspectives, further exploration could delve into the optimization of reaction conditions to enhance the catalytic efficiency of the herein presented complexes, particularly focusing on expanding the scope of substrates and alkylating agents to assess their versatility and applicability in diverse synthetic transformations. Additionally, elucidating the mechanistic intricacies underlying the observed trends in catalytic activity, as revealed by our computational analyses, could provide valuable insights for the rational design of even more efficient chiral salen complexes for future asymmetric Cα-alkylation reactions. 4 Experimental and note 4.1 Materials All reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was carried out on aluminum foil backed sheets precoated with 0.2 mm Kielselgel 60 F254 (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany). The spots were visualized by UV irradiation (λ=254 nm). Column chromatography was performed on Fluka silica gel 60 (0.063–0.200 mm, 70–320 mesh) on a glass column. 4.2 Instrumentation Melting points (mp) were determined by digital melting point instrument Stuart SMP30 Melting Point (Bibby Scientific Limited, Staffordshire England, UK). NMR spectra were recorded in deuterated solvents using Varian Mercury Vx 300 MHz (USA, Palo-Alto) and BRUKER AVANCE NEO 400 in the case of the 15 compound. Chemical shifts (δ) are reported in parts per million (ppm) relative to tetramethyl silane. Signals were referenced to the residual solvent peak 7.26 (CDCl3), 3.31 (CD3OD), 4.79 (D2O), 2.50 ((CD3)2SO) for 1H and 77.10 (CDCl3), 49.15 (CD3OD), 39.52 ((CD3)2SO) for 13C NMR spectra. The 13C NMR spectra were measured with proton decoupling. Coupling constants are reported in Hertz (Hz). Abbreviations for splitting patterns are as follows: s, singlet; d, doublet; t, triplet; q, quartet; qt, quintet; sext, sextet; hept, heptet; m, multiplet; br., broad. The optical rotation was measured on a Perkin Elmer-341 polarimeter (Waltham, Massachusetts, USA). Elemental analysis was performed by “Euro EA3000” elemantal analyzer (Eurovector, Pavia, Italy). For the cation exchange a Dowex-50 (H+ form) column was used. The chromatographic system used to determine the enantiomeric purity of the amino acids was a Waters Alliance 2695e Separation Module HPLC system equipped with PDA detector (Waters Corporation, Milford, Massachusetts, USA). The separation was accomplished in isocratic mode on a Nautilus-E 5µ” 4.0 × 250 mm column (BioChimMac ST Company, Moscow, Russia) at 30 °C. The mobile phase consisted of methanol and monosodium phosphate buffer (25 mmol/L). The compounds enantiomeric yield was proved by chiral HPLC analysis of the isolated amino acids. The RAMAN analyses was done by Senterra II Raman Microscope (Bruker, Germany). The IR analysis were done by IR Tracer-100, equipped with GladiATR 10, Shimadzu corporation, Japan and NICOLET AVATAR 330 FT-IR. The asymmetric yield is calculated as the value of three measurements. Theoretical calculation methodology All theoretical calculations were performed in the framework of density functional theory (DFT) using the hybrid functional B3LYP [39] in the ORCA 5.0.3 program [40].The effect of the solvent was designed using the dielectric polarizable continuum model CPCM [41] with the dielectric constant corresponding to CH2Cl2 solvent, as implemented in ORCA 5.0.3. The optimized geometries were obtained using the def2-TZVP basis set of the Alrich's def2 family [42] with the def2/J auxiliary set. To calculate the vibrational energy of the resulting def2-TZVP geometries, the basis was retained only for the atoms included in the core of the transition metal complex, i.e. for Cu/Zn, O, N, Na, and for the rest of the hydrocarbon core the lighter def2-SVP was used. The dispersion correction to the electronic energy D3BJ was also taken into account according to Grimme, et al. [43]. Computations were performed on the NVIDIA DGX A100 cluster which was acquired by the RA MES State Committee of Science grant project № 10–3/22Eq-10. 4.3 General method for synthesis (1S,2S)-diaminocyclohexane The synthesis of (1S,2S)-diaminocyclohexane was performed following a previously reported method [44]. Chemical yield 20 % (10 % of the side product), (0.100 g) yellow powder. Mp dec. 360 °C without melting. 3rd step: Synthesis of binuclear dimeric complex of the Cu(II) ( 16 ) Chemical yield 71 % (0.876 g), yellow powder. Mp dec. 360 °C without melting. Elemental analysis: found C, 58.93; H, 5.09; N, 5.68; calculated for C46H44Cu2N4O4 *Cu(OAc)2: C, 58.56; H, 4.91; N, 5.46. Since the obtained complex 16 could not be dissolved in anything, we were not able to perform an NMR analysis. For the chemical characterization, compound 16 was analyzed using Raman microscopy. However, it was observed that compound 16 decomposed under the laser during the Raman analysis. Consequently, infrared (IR) spectroscopy was employed for further analysis. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we present a series of Zn(II) mono- and Cu(II) binuclear salen complexes synthesized and assessed for their effectiveness in the Cα-alkylation reaction. Through systematic experimentation, it was observed that the introduction of a methoxy group at position 3 of the phenyl group in the salicylidene ligand led to a notable enhancement in asymmetric yield, while an allyl group reduced yield. Computational DFT calculations supported the involvement of the binuclear complex in the transition state of the reaction, elucidating the underlying mechanisms governing the observed catalytic behavior. A newly synthesized binuclear complex exhibited significantly higher catalytic activity compared to its mononuclear counterpart which could potentially be explained by increased intramolecular rigidity. This comprehensive investigation not only advances our understanding of structure-activity relationships in chiral salen complexes but also provides valuable insights for the rational design and optimization of catalysts for the asymmetric Cα-alkylation reaction.

coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and evaluation of new mono- and binuclear salen complexes for the Cα-alkylation reaction of amino acid substrates as chiral phase transfer catalysts
